reviewText: This offer from Warner Brothers at the $500+ launch price only makes sense if you want to start a blu ray collection from scratch and desperately want all the names in the 50 film collection right now regardless of the price. The collection is very much a mixed bag though half of the titles are AFI top 100 names worth owning. You can buy the worthy names that interest you on Amazon separately or alternatively wait about a year when this box set collection will be selling for about $150. If you want this box set, patience will be rewarded otherwise I would pass. Just my recommendation.
Title: N/A

reviewText: These are the cream of the crop of Warner movies over the decades (even though almost a third are MGM titles acquired from a merger decades ago). For those new to blu, this is the box set of a lifetime. If you're a snob when it comes to black and white films you might not be as enamored of this set, but the color titles remaining are still enough to make this a great deal! Most of these are loaded with extras. I personally won't buy it because I already own all but ten of these. I couldn't recommend it more to people who want to start their collection with a very nice set, though!
Title: N/A

reviewText: While all of the movies are great, the way these types of boxed sets are being packaged will eventually scratch the discs to the point where they are unviewable. If the companies would just put them in slim sleeves they would last a lot longer.
Title: N/A

reviewText: ... bunches of these films were not even released by Warner Brothers. They are now owned by Warner Brothers, which has the largest film library in the world. This collection include the films of MGM, RKO, New Line Cinema, and various other films that somehow found their way into the Warner Brothers film library. For that matter why not include some of the films whose distribution rights were sold to Warner Brothers last year by the Sam Goldwyn estate? They have as much to do with Warner Brothers the studio and its history as Grand Hotel and Mutiny on the Bounty, both made during the Irving Thalberg era of MGM.Is this a five star collection of films? Certainly. I subtract two stars for trotting out the same old titles again and again and I subtract another star for just plain trying to pull the wool over my eyes and doing a bad job of it at that.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I love this set...I am so excited to watch some of these old films like " The Shining" and " North by Northwest" in blue ray!The only thing I didn't really like so much was the way the blue rays are stored.  The come in two "Books" and its made of cardboard.  So I am worried that eventually it may scratch them up taking them in and out; but I am going to go and buy some disc cases and put them in there.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was looking at this as more a gift for my brother who recently got a BD player and doesn't own a lot of movies. Pretty much every movie on here is good, although many may only be worth seeing once. For the price on sale, is a good set. Regularly priced would not be.  Not really fair for people to give poor reviews because they already own the movies.
summary: really is a great set of movies, great if on sale
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is studio disconnect at it's worst.  The set crosses multiple genres, many of which somebody is not going to want.  I am pretty open about movies but many of the films hold no appeal.  Plus, many of the films I have already purchased as they have been out for a long time.  If you actually want people to buy your set, confine yourself to one genre and release mostly new content.  Only film historians are going to want this and that is a very small demographic.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Does anyone remember a movie called "Enter the Dragon" starring Bruce Lee?  A movie that grossed a ton of money internationally?  Where is it?  It's not in this collection.  As others have pointed out some other great classics, this one deserved to be on the list as well.  Don't call it "Best" of anything.  Just call it 50 random movies.
summary: Don't call it the "Best" if the best isn't on here
Title: N/A

reviewText: I suppose that if you don't have a DVD collection, this might be a good way to start one since many of the movies are indeed excellent. If you're the average movie fan though, I suspect that like me you already own most of these, and the ones I don't own I don't really want. The price seems to have come down quite a bit, so at less than $4 a film it's a fair deal and the beginning collector should also appreciate the compact packaging, or you will in the future when your walls are lined with DVD's (and that day will probably come for you like it did for me).
Title: N/A

reviewText: ... are the Brothers Warner - Jack, Harry, Sam and Albert - spinning in their graves.What a travesty!  As other reviewers have already pointed out, most of the films included in this "Best of Warner Brothers" collection were neither produced nor released by that legendary studio. And this grab-bag isn't representative of the studio's rich history or its hallmark early style: tough, gritty, fast-moving crowd-pleasers that included some of the key films in the gangster, musical, and biographical genres.But what makes this collection a joke is not only what was included ... it's what was left out!  None of the films produced under the studio's prolific First National banner are included, so you won't find such landmark films such as "Little Caesar" (1930), the Oscar-nominated "Flirtation Walk" (1934), or the award-winning "Angels with Dirty Faces" (1938) among the mix.  Where is "The Jazz Singer" (1927), the film that ushered in the sound era?  Or any of the famous Busby Berkeley musicals like "42nd Street" (1932) or "Gold Diggers of 1933"?  Or Best Picture Oscar winners "The Life of Emile Zola" (1937) and "My Fair Lady" (1964)?  Or Bette Davis' Best Actress winning turn as "Jezebel" (1938)?  Where are the box office blockbusters, historical standard bearers, and critical smashes like "Public Enemy" (1931), "Mystery of the Wax Museum" (1933), "The Story of Louis Pasteur" (1936), "Dark Victory" (1939), "Sergeant York" (1941), "Yankee Doodle Dandy" (1942), "Now, Voyager" (1942), "Mildred Pierce" (1945), "Key Largo" (1948), "A Star is Born" (1954), "East of Eden" (1955), "Giant" (1956) ... etc., etc.?  The list of what legitimately could and should have been included goes on and on.Looking over the list of films in this package, it quickly becomes obvious that some misguided and cynical marketing executive took a look at the library titles that had previously been released on blu-ray, and decided to repackage them along with a couple of new documentaries to make a quick buck.  No, thank you, I won't even be interested in this set when it eventually (and inevitably) becomes a close-out item at 75% - 90% off the original suggested retail price.  The Warner Brothers and we, the public, deserve better.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Glancing at the just published Press Releases for this box set, out of the 16 earliest films featured in this set 10 of them were made and released by studios other than Warner Bros!Absolutely outrageous disregard for anything approaching film history - you've got films like Broadway Melody, Grand Hotel, Gone with the Wind and Citizen Kane that were MGM, Selznick and RKO releases, to name just four! They've been released on Warner branded DVD in the past 10 years simply because Ted Turner bought up all the rights in the 80s.It's a very sorry affair that speaks volumes about Hollywood's constant disregard for it's own history.
summary: Celebrate 90 years of Warners by watching films released by other studios!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was surprised that Giant was not included in this set, thus the three star rating. Hard to believe it didn't make the cut. The discs are good quality and the organization makes it easy to find a film.
Title: N/A

reviewText: NOT ONE Bette Davis or James Cagney film! Two of Warner Brothers powerhouses! And the price is outrageous, considering most collectors have at least half these titles already.

reviewText: This is a great collection of movies. I had already owned 9 of these movies, but figured it was worth the price to get all the others. Bonus is the UltraViolet Digital Copies. I was concerned about how these were going to be redeemable. I was pleased to see that it was one (1) code to enter. It took a couple minutes to load all the movies, but it did include all 50 digital copies. The best thing was that the 9 movies I already had didn't originally have the digital copies, so I didn't have any duplicates there.The case was a little confusing to open at first. The front lifts up and back to reveal the two book-like cases inside. It is a really neat design. I was wondering how to display these with my other movie collection, and decided to keep them in this original box, all together. I love movies and have a large collection (over 500) so this was a must for me.
Title: N/A

reviewText: After reading some of the more intelligent reviews of this supposed WB collection I can only throw in my hat with those who see this as a mis-labled collection comprised of many MGM spectaculars (as well as other studios scavanged by Turner and then WB) which the Warner Bros. had NO HAND in creating, but merely were the spoils of corporate takeovers and greed.  And yes, if you are a cineaste you will probably have many of the offered dvds.  I believe that corporate greed is the ultimate destruction of true artistic creativity and a valid historical line of who actually created what.  The same with Universal and their appropriation of, among other titles, Hitchcock's Paramount output.  Just because you bought a Monet doesn't mean you created it....get real moneymen, you will never rise to the heights of true creativity by usurping someone else's work.  Ever think of "reaching for the stars" with some of your corporate-acaquired lucre and make something great on your own.  And as Mammy Yokum would say, "I HAS SPOKEN!"
summary: WHAT WAS THEIR CREATIVITY IS NOW MINE!!!!!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Did anyone else notice how FEW titles are from the Golden Age of movie making, and how the vast majority are from the 1980's, until today.If I want to buy a collection, I would prefer that its be a CLASSICS collection, from the 1910's, through the 1950's, NOT the modern stuff, which one can buy ANYWHERE.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The choice of movies included gives one a grand cross-sectional view of the ever changing perceptions of what makes a great movie.  There's something for everyone in this collection and I find it provides hours of entertainment for the price.My only regret is that there are no iTunes codes.  The buyer is stuck with the prospect of dealing with Sony's UltraViolet "digital" copy.  After my 4th purchase that only provided UV, I've decided to avoid purchasing any movies that only provide that option.I'd have given this collection 5 stars had it also included iTunes codes in the package.
summary: Great selection - but seriously - UltraViolet again?
Title: N/A

reviewText: While the special price is excellent, and this is a fine "starter" collection, not providing it in a digital format that can be used without all the inherent hassles and short lifespan of UltraViolet diminishes the value of this collection to the point that it is really of no interest to me. A true digital copy is playable on virtually any platform and any player, from iTunes to VLC, etc.
Title: N/A

reviewText: What can one say, but it's great fun watching these movies chosen to represent Warner Brothers films over the years. Quality is excellent on even the oldest movies. I discovered movies I had heard about but never seen, plus movies, I had just plain forgotten. A pleasant collection.
summary: It contains many great classics, including some newer ones.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Best of Warner Bros 50 Film Collection [Blu-ray]  It must have been a salesman at Time/Warner that selected these films.  Most of the best pictures on the list aren't even Warner Brothers films.  Yet, they've left off such great Warner Brothers films like, My Fair Lady, The Pajama Game, Gypsy, The Music Man, Giant, etc. I could go on and on and those are just the Warner musicals. If you listen carefully you can hear Jack Warner SCREAMING.

reviewText: At under $200, this Warner Collection is a bargain just for the 50 HD Ultraviolet Digital Copies Alone.Albeit, the digital copies are only available for streaming via your Flixster account. This is the only platform I know that doesn't make ultraviolet redemptions available on other linked viewing platforms.

reviewText: WOW! The movies I have watched so far from this collection look great!  I don't waste money on cable. So I have a budget for buying blue ray. This was the best blue ray purchase I have made. 50 Great films. I know I always have something worth wile to watch! No Honey BOO BOO tho'. I call that a win win!
summary: A great buy for the movie lover.
